sub_topic: Calculation of thermodynamic properties of a mixture.
message_1: A physics student needs to calculate the specific heat capacity of a gas mixture made up of 75% nitrogen and 25% oxygen at a pressure of 1 atm and a temperature of 300 K. Given that the specific heat capacity of pure nitrogen is 1.04 J/g.K and that of pure oxygen is 0.92 J/g.K, determine the specific heat capacity of the mixture in J/g.K.
message_2:
To calculate the specific heat capacity of the gas mixture, we can use a weighted average based on the percentages of each gas in the mixture. 

Specific heat capacity of the mixture (C_mix) = (Percentage of Nitrogen × Specific heat capacity of Nitrogen) + (Percentage of Oxygen × Specific heat capacity of Oxygen)

Given:
Percentage of Nitrogen = 75%
Percentage of Oxygen = 25%
Specific heat capacity of Nitrogen (C_N2) = 1.04 J/g.K
Specific heat capacity of Oxygen (C_O2) = 0.92 J/g.K

C_mix = (0.75 × C_N2) + (0.25 × C_O2)
C_mix = (0.75 × 1.04 J/g.K) + (0.25 × 0.92 J/g.K)
C_mix = (0.78 J/g.K) + (0.23 J/g.K)
C_mix = 1.01 J/g.K

The specific heat capacity of the gas mixture is 1.01 J/g.K.
